“EDERAL GOVERNMENT AND STATES
U.S. DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, EDUCATION, AND WELFARE OFFICE OF EDUCATION
ISSUED ANNUALLY
The Education Directory of the Office of Education is issued annually in the following parts:
*]. Federal Government and States. 2. Counties and Cities. 3. Higher Education.
1. Education Associations.
As soon as each part is off the press, copies may be purchased at nominal cost through the Superin- tendent of Documents, U.S. Government Printing Office, Washington 25. D.C.
*Part 1. Federal Government and States was prepared by Louse Ratliff Vurphy, Research Assistant in State School Administration,
U.S. DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, EDUCATION, AND WELFARE Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary
GCffice of Education Lawrence G. Derthick, Commissioner
United States Government Printing Office, Washington : 1960. For sale by the Superintendent of Documents, U.S, Government Printing Office, Washington 25,D.C. - - - ~~ Brice 30 cents

Page REO MP DATOATION 9.02020 on. ooo Se eee Seas - a ----- see ace 3 PRINCIPAL STATE AND TERRITORIAL SCHOOL OFFICERS____..--.-------- 14 ExEcuTIVE OFFICERS OF STATE AND TERRITORIAL LIBRARY EXTENSION RNG OY, 2 ee... Seen ie = Se)? 79 PRINCIPAL EDUCATION OFFICERS OF THE BUREAU OF INDIAN AFFAIRS_-_-- 82 INTRODUCTION
This directory is a listing of the education officials in the Office of Education, the principal State and Territorial school officers, the executive officers of the State and Territorial library extension agen- cies, and the principal education officers of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, Department of the Interior. It has two major purposes: (1) To present a listing of professional personnel in the agencies con- cerned; and (2) To show the internal organization of the Office of Education and the State departments of education. It is hoped that the information in the Directory will be helpful in identifying the individuals in each agency with whom directory users may wish to communicate.
CRITERIA FOR LISTING
Use was made of the following criteria in determining what officers of the State departments of education should be included or excluded:
For wncluston:
1, All regularly employed professional personnel of the State department of education who report directly or through a superior to the chief State school officer and whose duties are statewide in scope.
For exclusion:
1. All field or regional personnel (supervisors, consultants, counselors, etc.) of the State department of education who are under the immediate supervision of an officer of the department other than the chief State school officer
1
9 EDUCATION DIRECTORY, 1960-61
and whose duties encompass only a certain geographical portion of the State.
2. All personnel of State-operated schools, libraries, muse- ums, radio stations, etc., which are administered through the State department of education, except the heads of such State-operated programs who provide a specialized statewide service to schools and school personnel or who are recognized as bureau or division heads in the department.
ARRANGEMENT OF DATA |
In the listing of Principal State and Territorial School Officers, the — data are arranged to reflect the organization of the departments of | education through the indentation of official titles. The official titles of the chief school officer and all professional personnel under his immediate supervision form the basis for indentation. All profes- sional personnel directly responsible to an official other than the chief school officer are listed under that official, and the relationship is shown
by an appropriate indentation.

1 All public schools in Hawaii, with the exception of the University of Hawaii, are under the operational control of the State board of education. This board has full authority and responsibility for the adminis- tration of the State department of public instruction.
2 The district superintendents of the 4 districts in Hawaii are directly responsible to the superintendent of public instruction, who is the administrative officer of the State board of education.

Seventh-Day Adventist Schools
SPECIAL NOTE
We YEAR the Education Directory, Part 2, has been reevaluated, redesigned, and expanded. In the recent past, this directory listed (a) the county, supervisory district or union, administrative and di- vision school superintendents for States having such school officers, and (6) superintendents of those city, town, and urban place school systems which in 1950 had a population of 2,500 or more. This procedure omitted the names of superintendents of many local inde- pendent school systems not in either of these categories. Further- more, the use of the decennial census population figures meant that in recent directories of this series, some city, town, and urban place listings were as much as 9 or 10 years out of date. To eliminate these important gaps, it was decided to (a) list superintendents of all independent school systems regardless of population size and (0) use reasonably current school enrollment data rather than population figures, in order to present a more precise picture of the size of school systems involved.
This new list indicates that public school superintendents in 50 States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico are administering school systems with a total enrollment of approximately 35.7 million pupils.
The church-related school lists this year have been increased from the membership of two to five nationwide church school organizations.
il
COUNTY, CITY, AND OTHER SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENCIES
Introduction
THIs DIRECTORY lists the superintendents of public school systems for all counties, supervisory districts or unions, regions, cities, towns, and other independent school systems in the United States and Puerto Rico. Included also are lists of superintendents or their counterparts in church-related schools of five church organizations which maintain schools on a regional or national basis.
Data included in this publication, with the exception of enrollment data, are based upon lists of superintendents of local schools supplied by the State departments of education. It is the objective of the U.S. Office of Education to maintain an accurate listing for directory users who wish to communicate with the school officers. To assure the greatest possible accuracy, these lists were sent back to the State departments of education for final review and verification as late as November 1960. The church-related school lists were supplied by the national offices of the five church organizations included.
TYPES OF SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENCIES INCLUDED
County and supervisory district or union superintendencies.—The county constitutes an area for public school administration in all of the States except Alaska, Delaware, Hawaii, New York, and the six New England States. There are two basic types of county school administration: the county-intermediate and the county-unit system.
The county-intermediate system is the traditional and the most prev- alent form of county school administration. It exists in areas where the local independent school district prevails as the basic adminis- trative unit, primarily in the Midwest and the Far West. The inter- mediate system is a unit of school administration that performs admin- istrative and supervisory functions and provides supplementary educational services in a designated area comprised of two or more local administrative units. Under this type of organization, the county school superintendent generally serves as an intermediary between the basic local administrative units and the State department
1
2 EDUCATION DIRECTORY, 1960-61
of education. However, the specific functions and degree of inde- pendence of this type of district vary from State to State. Many of the school systems are of the county-intermediate type in the following States :
Arizona Michigan Oklahoma Arkansas Minnesota Oregon California Mississippi Pennsylvania Colorado Missouri South Dakota Idaho Montana Texas
Illinois Nebraska Washington Indiana New Jersey Wisconsin Iowa North Dakota Wyoming Kansas Ohio
The county-unit school system, on the other hand, is a countywide, basic administrative unit. It is most prevalent in the Southeastern States, but is showing an increase in other States. County-unit school districts are of two types: complete and partial. A complete county-unit school system includes all public schools of the county. In this type of school system, the administrative policies are set by a single board and carried out by a single superintendent. There is but one educational budget and one center of administrative con- trol in the entire unit. All public school systems in the States of Florida, Maryland (except the city of Baltimore, which is a separate political entity), Nevada, and West Virginia are organized exclu- sively on a complete county-unit system basis. Many of the counties in the States of Alabama, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Utah operate a complete county- unit system; the remaining counties in these States have partial county-unit systems.
A partial county-unit school system includes all schools of a county with the exception of one or more independent districts, generally the school system of a city or town, located within the county. One example of a partial county-unit school system is that of Jefferson County, Kentucky, which administers all the public schools within the county except for the schools of the city of Louisville and the town of Anchorage, each of which is an independnent school system.
“Supervisory district” or “union” is the term for the intermediate type of school district in the New England States. Those New England town school systems which are too small, individually, to employ a superintendent full time, form parts of supervisory unions consisting of two or more towns. Such unions employ a single superintendent to serve all the towns in the union. Similarly, the
INTRODUCTION 34
New York State school systems, which are outside of city or village districts, have combined to form supervisory school districts, each of which employs a full-time superintendent of the supervisory district.
The town or city organization (and the more recently organized School Administrative District in Maine) constitutes the basic unit for school administration in New England.
Independent and other school superintendencies.—‘ Independent school superintendents” are those through whom direct contact is made concerning the public school districts of a particular State.
The school systems of all cities, towns, villages, boroughs, consoli- dations, and joimtures that are independent systems are listed in this directory under the county in which they are located.
The school systems in cities or towns not listed in this directory operate under the supervision or jurisdiction of the superintendent of the county or union in which they are located. Directory users who wish to contact school officials in these districts should write to the county or union superintendents.
In the State of Virginia, a “division,” the official designation for a school district in the State, normally consists of either a single county or a single city. In some instances, however, a division con- sists of two counties or a county and a city.
In Utah, although most of the school districts are organized and administered as complete county-unit systems, some counties are divided into 2 or 8 districts, each of which has its own school superintendent.
In Delaware, any administrative function not discharged by the local school district is performed by the State department of education.
Superintendents of church-related schools——These superintendents, area directors, and diocesan school officers, with their addresses, are listed as follows:
Catholic parochial schools—by archdiocese and diocese. Jewish schools (area directors)—by city area agency. Lutheran parochial schools—by supervisory district.
Protestant Episcopal schools—by diocese. Seventh-Day Adventist schools—by union or local conference.
SOURCE OF ENROLLMENT DATA
Enrollment data for individual school systems were obtained by a mail survey conducted from April to June 1960 by the Bureau of the Census at the request of the U.S. Office of Education. In
4 EDUCATION DIRECTORY, 1960-61
this survey each county superintendent was asked to bring the 1957 Census of Governments? listing of school systems in his county up to date. The data shown here for public enrollment are based on a summation of enrollment figures obtained for individual school systems by this mail survey. Officials were asked to report the total number of pupils enrolled in each system as of October 31, 1959, or the nearest later date for which enrollment information was avail- able. Although most of the replies gave information for an October or late September date, reports of enrollment as of the other dates in the 1959-60 school year were also accepted and used. Where enrollment data were not available from the census survey, 1958-59 or later enrollment data available from the State school directories were used.
When the lists were sent out for final review and verification before the printing deadline, several States included enrollment data as of September 1960. Where this is the case, it 1s indicated at the beginning of the State list.
ARRANGEMENT OF DATA
1. States are listed in alphabetical order.
2. Within each State, counties are listed alphabetically, and the information appears in the ensuing order after the county name: a. Number of school systems under the jurisdiction or supervision
of the county or union superintendent (in parentheses). b. Combined enrollment in these systems (in parentheses). c. Name of the county superintendent. d. Mailing address of the county school system.
3. Independent school systems, located within the county but gen- erally independent of the county superintendent, are listed alpha- betically within the county and are indented one space to the right. The following information for these systems appears after the name of the independent city or town:
a. Enrollment (in parentheses). b. Name of superintendent. c. Post office address (if different from name of district). Example: In the State of Indiana— BARTHOLOMEW (9) (2,391)—Joseph 8. Foust, Columbus
Columbus (6,617)—Clarence Robbins Flatrock-Hawcreek Cons. (921)—Llioyd Shoyer, Hope
11957 Census of Governments, Vol. I, No. 1, U.S. Bureau of the Census, Washington, IDO. Oe.
INTRODUCTION 5)
Exceptions to this arrangement of data are found in those States that do not maintain the office of county superintendent of schools or any type of county school organization. The type of school organ- ization in States in this latter category is explained in the paragraph preceding the particular State’s listing.
In cases where urban schools in New England are administered by superintendents of supervisory or superintendency districts or unions, the number of the union or the name of the district is given.
Some States have separate districts for elementary and for sec- ondary schools; others maintain elementary districts only, with a separate high school district encompassing a larger area, such as the county. Where this is true, the districts are designated as “Elem.” or “High,” and the superintendent for each is listed.

School Superintendencies, by State
(Where the name of the school district or system is the same as that of the post office address, the post office address is not repeated.)
ALABAMA
County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 114 school superintendencies in the State, including 35 complete
county-unit and 32 partial county-unit superintendencies.
The remaining 47
are independent city or town school superintendencies located within the 32
partial county-unit counties.

EDUCATION DIRECTORY, 1960-61
ALASKA
Independent District Superintendencies
There are 29 independent district school superintendencies in the State.
All
public schools are under the supervision of the superintendent of the independent district in which they are located. ‘There are no county superintendents of
schools in the State.

ARIZONA
County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 47 school superintendencies in the State: 14 county intermediate and 83 independent district superintendencies. The superintendents of the 14 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Ham- blin’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in Apache County (13) and the total number of pupils enrolled in these districts
(4,332).

Winslow (2,786)—R. E. Booth ward Pima (14) (6,731)—Florence Reece, Yuma High (2,300)—Warren R. Tucson Sirrine ARKANSAS
County and Independent Schoo! Supervisors
The school district administrators are referred to as school supervisors rather than school superintendents. There are 407 school supervisors in the State: 40 are county-intermediate supervisors, 35 are partial county-unit supervisors, and 382 are independent city or town supervisors. In the 40 county-intermediate counties, the supervisor performs inainly a service function. Where this is true, it is indicated by (0) (0): zero districts, zero enrollment.

SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENCIES—CALIFORNIA lf
CALIFORNIA County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 917 school superintendencies in the State, including 52 county- intermediate superintendencies, 4 complete county-unit superintendencies, and 2 partial county-unit superintendencies. The remaining 859 are independent city or town superintendencies. The superintendents in 51 of the 52 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent LaFleche’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in Alameda County (9) and the total number of pupils enrolled in these districts (635). The one remaining county superintendent performs mainly a service function, indicated by (0) (0) : zero districts, zero enrollment data.
Technically, all school districts in this State are under the county superin- tendent. However, there are “unified school districts” which are largely self- contained, having elementary, high school, and junior college levels within the organization. In other cases, the elementary, high school, and junior college districts exist separately. Such districts are designated as “Elem.” or “High”; junior college districts are not included here because they are listed in part 3 of the Education Directory.

SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENCIES—COLORADO Sill COLORADO
County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 286 school superintendencies in the State: 56 county-intermediate superintendencies, 6 partial county-unit superintendencies, one complete county- unit superintendency, and 228 independent city or town superintendencies.
The superintendents in 22 of the 56 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Heid’s name are shown the number of dis- tricts whose functions she administers in Adams County (8) and the total num- ber of pupils enrolled in these districts (456).
In the remaining 34 counties, the county superintendent performs mainly a service function. Where this is true, it is indicated by (0) (0): zero districts, zero enrollment data.

SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENCIES—CONNECTICUT
CONNECTICUT
Supervisory Union, Regional High School, and Independent Superin- tendencies
There are 125 school superintendencies in the State: 14 union superintend- encies, 8 regional high school superintendencies, and 103 independent city or town superintendencies. There are no county school superintendents in the State. A number of towns have jointly employed a superintendent to administer all the schools within their boundaries. These combinations (supervisory unions) do not have a name or number; therefore, all town schools administered by the same superintendent are listed alphabetically before the superintendent’s name.
The 8 regional high school superintendencies are listed by number.
SUPERVISORY UNION

SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENCIES—DELAWARE
Oo”
DELAWARE
Independent District Superintendencies
There are 93 independent
Of the 93 independent school districts, 77 are
ealled “State Board Unit Districts” and are listed by number and name. These
77 districts are administered by a Supervising principal or head teacher.
The
remaining 16 districts are called “Special Districts” and are administered by a
school superintendent.
143

DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA

FLORIDA
County Superintendencies
The State of Florida has a complete county-unit school system composed of
67 county-unit superintendencies.
All public schools in cities and towns are
administered by the superintendent of schools of the county in which they are
located.

GEORGIA
County and Independent Superintendencies
There are 198 school superintendencies in the State: 124 complete county-unit superintendencies, 35 partial county-unit superintendencies, and 39 independent city, or town superintendencies located within the 35 partial county-unit
counties.

SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENCIES—HAWAIL 43
HAWAII District Superintendencies
There are no county school superintendents in the State; instead there are 4 administrative district school superintendencies. Enrollment data are as of
September 1960. Hawaii (17,277) —Ralph Kiyosaki, Hilo] Maui-Kalawao (11,032)—James W. Honolulu (109,614)—Charles B. Bar- O’Neal, Kahului rett Kauai Lihue
(6,769)—Malcolm W. Clower,
IDAHO County, Joint, and Independent Superintendencies
The office of County School Superintendent has almost been abolished in Idaho. Of the 44 counties in the State, 4 have superintendents and 2 have clerks of the county boards of education administering the schools in the nonreorgan- ized areas in their particular counties. All six of these officers serve on a part-time basis. In the other 115 school districts, 43 are joint and 72 are inde- pendent city or town superintendencies. The superintendents of the 4 county superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Perry’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions she administers in Canyon County (17)
and the total number of pupils enrolled in these districts (1,202).

46 EDUCATION DIRECTORY, 1960-61
ILLINOIS Couniy and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 1,667 school superintendencies in the State: 93 county-intermediate superintendencies, 9 partial county-unit superintendencies, 1,565 city or town superintendencies. The superintendents in 15 of the 98 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Supt. Dennison’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in Henderson County (4) and the total number of pupils enrolled in these district (198). In the remaining 7S counties, the county superintendent performs mainly a service function. Where this is true, it is indicated by (0) (0) : zero districts, zero enrollment data.

INDIANA
County, Joint, Consolidated, Metropoliian, and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 296 school stperintendencies in the State, including 85 county- intermediate and 3 partial county-unit superintendencies. Of the remaining 208, 5 are joint, 32 are consolidated, 24 are metropolitan, and 146 are independent city or town superintendencies. The superintendents of the 85 county-intermedi- ate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Feuerbach’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in Allen County
(12) and the total number of pupils enrolled in his districts (5,832).

1 County school corporation.
2The office of county school superintend- ent has been abolished. All schools in this county are under the supervision of the superintendents of the local school districts in which they are located.
72
EDUCATION DIRECTORY, 1960-61
IOWA County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 658 school superintendencies in the State: 79 county-intermediate superintendencies, 20 partial county-unit superintendencies, and 559 independent city or town superintendencies. The superintendents in 54 of the 79 county- intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools in- dependently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Southard’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in Benton County (4) and the total number of pupils enrolled in these districts (266). In the remaining 25 counties, the county superintendent performs mainly a service function. Where this is true, it is indicated by (0) (0) : zero districts,
zero enrollment data.

EDUCATION DIRECTORY, 1960-61
KANSAS
County and independent School Superintendencies
There are 449 school superintendencies in the State: 103 county-intermediate superintendencies, 2 partial county-unit superintendencies, and 344 independent
city or town superintendencies.
The superintendents of the 103 county super-
intendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Sage’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions she administers in Allen County (17) and the total number of pupils enrolled in these districts (963).

SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENCIES—KENTUCKY
85
KENTUCKY
County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 212 school superintendencies in the State, including 56 complete
county-unit and 64 partial county-unit superintendencies.
The remaining 92
are independent city or town superintendencies located within the 64 partial
county-unit counties.

LOUISIANA
—
Parish and Independent School Superintendencies There are 67 school superintendencies in the State: 61 complete county-unit © superintendencies, 8 partial county-unit superintendencies, and 3 independ- ent city superintendencies located within the 3 partial county-unit counties. The Parish in Louisiana is a civil division which corresponds to a county in
other States.

Supervisory Union, Administrative, and Independent School Superin- tendencies
There are 121 school superintendencies in the State: 92 supervisory union,
16 administrative, and 13 independent city superintendencies. county school superintendents in the State.
There are no The general administration of
public schools is under the supervision of a supervisory union, adininistrative,
or independent city superintendent.
In this State, two or more towns combine
to form union superintendencies, each of which employs a superintendent who
has jurisdiction over all schools in the union.
number. rollment data are as of September 1960.

MARYLAND
County and Independent Superintendencies
The State has a complete county-unit school system except for the city of Baltimore, which has its own independent school system. Therefore, there are 23 county-unit superintendencies and one independent school superintendency in
the State.
All other public schools in cities and towns in Maryland are under
the supervision of the superintendent of schools of the county in which they are
located.

MASSACHUSETTS
Superintendency Union, Regional High School, and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 252 school superintendencies in the State: 55 union superinten- dencies, 24 regional high school superintendencies, and 173 independent city or
town superintendencies. State. a union, regional or independent, city or town superintendent.
There are no county school superintendents in the The general administration of public schools is under the supervision of
In this State,
two or more towns combine to form a union or regional superintendency, each of which employs a superintendent who has jurisdiction over all schools in the union or region. Each union is designated by number and each region is des- ignated by name.

MICHIGAN County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 757 school superintendencies in the State: 79 county-intermediate superintendencies, 4 partial county-unit superintendencies, and 674 independent city or town superintendencies. The superintendents in 74 of the 79 county- intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Erick- son’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in Aleona county (3) and the total number of pupils enrolled in these districts (1,298). In the remaining 5 counties, the county superintendent performs mainly a service function. Where this is true, it is indicated by (0) (0): zero districts, zero enrollment data.

106 EDUCATION DIRECTORY, 1960-61
MINNESOTA
County, Independent, Special, Common, and Unorganized Territory School Superintendencies
There are 562 school superintendencies in the State, including 77 county- intermediate, 2 complete county-unit, 8 partial county-unit, and 468 city or town superintendencies. Of the remaining 12 included in this list, 6 are special, 3 are common and 3 are unorganized territory superintendencies.’
The superintendents in 73 of the 77 county-intermediate superintendencies per- form all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local dis- tricts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Newstrom’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions she administers in Aitkin County (14) and the total
number of pupils enrolled in these districts (403). the county superintendent performs mainly a service function.
In the remaining 4 counties, Where this is
true, it is indicated by (0) (0); zero districts, zero enrollment data.

The three counties having unorgan- ized territory areas are Cass, Koochiching, and St. Louis. 2 This school officer serves as county school administrator in addition to superintendent of an independent district.

MISSISSIPPi County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 163 school superintendencies in the State, including 30 complete county-unit, 40 partial county-unit, and 12 county-intermediate superintendencies. The remaining superintendencies listed show that 29 are consolidated and 52 are municipal separate school superintendencies. The county superintendent in the 12 county-intermediate counties in the State performs mainly a service func- tion. Where this is true, it is indicated by (0) (0); zero districts, zero enroll-
ment data.

SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENCIES—MISSOURI 115
MISSOURI County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 666 school superintendencies in the State: 102 county-intermediate superintendencies, 12 partial county-unit superintendencies, and 552 independent city or town superintendencies. The superintendents in 77 of the 102 county- intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools in- dependently. For example, in parentheses before Superintendent Purvis’ name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in Adair County (36) and the total number of pupils enrolled in these districts (504). In the remaining 25 counties, the county superintendent performs mainly a
service function. zero enrollment data.

MONTANA County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 245 school superintendencies in the State: 56 county-intermediate superintendencies, 9 county high school superintendencies, and 180 independent city or town superintendencies. The 9 county high school superintendencies are supervised by principals. Superintendents of the 56 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Stroeder’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions she administers in Beaverhead County (16) and the total number of pupils enrolled in these districts (203).

NEBRASKA County and Independent Schooi Superintendencies
There are 500 school superintendencies in the State: 91 county-intermediate superintendencies and 409 independent city or town superintendencies. The superintendents of the 91 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Harris’ name are shown the number of districts whose functions she administers in Adams County (19) and the total number of pupils
enrolled in these districts (349).

NEVADA
County Superintendencies
The State has a complete county-unit school system composed of 17 county-
unit superintendencies.
All public schools in cities and towns are administered
by the superintendent of schools of the county in which they are located. The
enrollment data are as of September 1960.

NEW HAMPSHIRE
Supervisory Union and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 48 school superintendencies in the State: 38 supervisory union and
10 independent city superintendencies. The general administratoin of public schools is under
tendents in the State.
the supervision of a supervisory union or independent city superintendent.
There are no county school superin-
In
this State, two or more towns combine to form a supervisory union superin- tendency; they employ a superintendent who has jurisdiction over all schools in the union. Each union listed is designated by number.

Dover (3,032)—Frederick C. Walker| Portsmouth (5,571)—Raymond I. Keene (3,643)—Lawrence O. Thomp- Beal son Rochester (2,384)—John H. Frye NEW JERSEY
County, Regional, and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 337 school superintendencies in the State: 21 county-intermediate, 31 regional high school, and 285 independent city or town superintendencies. The superintendents of the 21 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its school independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Helmbold’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in Atlantic County (9) and the total number of pupils enrolled in these districts (2,738).

NEW MEXICO
County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 90 school superintendents in the State; 8 partial county unit and 82 independent city or town superintendencies. Twenty-four counties in the
State do not have county school organizations.
Schools in these counties are
administered by local superintendents and are included in the independent city
or town superintendencies.

NEW YORK Supervising District, City, and Village Superintendencies
There are 298 school superintendencies in the State: 104 supervisory districts, 63 city, and 131 village superintendencies. There are no county school superin- tendents in the State; the general administration of schools is under the city, village, or district superintendent. District school superintendencies are desig- nated by number. City school superintendencies are indicated by an asterisk (*). The remaining named districts are village school districts.

NORTH CAROLINA
County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 173 school superintendencies in the State, including 49 complete county-unit and 51 partial county-unit superintendencies. Within the 51 partial county-unit counties are located 73 independent city or town superintendencies.

146 EDUCATION DIRECTORY, 1960-61
NORTH DAKOTA
County, Independent, Special, and Common School Superintendencies
There are 384 school superintendencies in the State: 53 county-intermediate . superintendencies, 175 independent city or town superintendencies, one common superintendency, and 155 special superintendencies. The superintendents of the 53 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Roberts’ name are shown the number of districts whose functions she admin- isters in Adams County (16) and the total number of pupils enrolled in these
districts (258).

SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENCIES—OHIO
151
OHIO
County ond Independent School Superintendencies
There are 305 school superintendencies in the State: 86 county-intermediate superintendencies, 1 complete county-unit superintendency, 1 partial county-unit
superintendency, and 217 independent city or town superintendencies.
The
superintendents of the 86 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Teets’ name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in Adams County (7) and the total number of pupils
enrolled in these districts (4,765).

SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENCIES—OKLAHOMA 155
OKLAHOMA County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 598 school superintendencies in the State: 77 county-intermediate superintendencies and 521 independent city or town superintendencies. ‘The superintendents of the 77 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the paren- theses before Superintendent Hallford’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in Adair County (28) and the total number of pupils enrolled in these districts (1,806).
Aparr (28) (1,806)—Jesse Haliford, Stilwell
Cave Springs (301)—D. M. Starr, Stilwell
Stilwell (1,046)—Kenneth Carleton Watts (282)—W. O. Cox Westville (551)—M. B. Traw ALFALFA (4) (845)—Ila Cranmer, Cherokee Aline (186)—Paul J. Outhier Burlington (140)—Ernest M. SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENCIES—OREGON 161
OREGON County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 157 school superintendencies in the State: 2 complete county-unit superintendencies, 3 partial county-unit superintendencies, 31 county-intermedi- ate superintendencies, and 121 independent city or town superintendencies. The superintendents of the 31 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all ad- ministrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Hall’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in Baker County (8) and the total number of pupils
enrolled in these districts (1,116).
BAKER (8) Baker Baker (2,423)—James R. Evans, BENTON (11) (1,002)—Helen P. Baker, Corvallis Corvallis (5,461)—Gerald R. Wal- lace, Philomath (1,019)—Henry O. Pete, CLACKAMAS (27) (2,592)—Leslie G. Rood, Oregon City Canby Elementary (786)—Paul Ack- erman Canby High (442)—Charles MacKen- zie Clackamas (587)—Walter Bilquist
(1,116)—Lowell L. Hall,
Concord (900)—Anton A. Bryant, Milwaukie
Hstacada Elementary (718)—Robert E. Cody
Estacada High (38938)—William R. Jones
Gladstone (674)—Walter L. Krax- berger
Lake Oswego (3,535)—Lawrence D. Fish, Oswego
Milwaukie Elementary (3,871)—Ar- thur Kiesz
Milwaukie High (1,992)—Owen O. Sabin
Molalla Elementary (644)—Thomas L. McBride
Molalla High (521)—J. C. Alexander
Oak Grove (637)—Earl Ladd
Oregon City (3,518)—Edwin Ditto

PENNSYLVANIA
County, Jointure, Union, and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 257 school superintendencies in the State of Pennsylvania: 64 county-intermediate superintendencies; 2 complete county-unit superintenden- cies; 139 independent city, township or borough superintendencies; 43 jointure’* superintendencies, and 9 union superintendencies. The superintendents of the 64 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Keefer’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in Adams County (6) and the total number of pupils enrolled in these districts
(4,847).
ADAMS (6) (4,847)—C. P. Keefer, Get- tysburg Gettysburg Jtr. Riegle Upper Adams (1,415)—Donald B. Hudson, Biglerville ALLEGHENY (60) (110,666)—Alfred W. Beattie, Pittsburgh Avalon (1,049)—James T. Jordan Bellevue (1,311)—Edwin B. Long

1The joint school plan used in Pennsyl- vania represents a contractual relationship between two or more school districts. As legal entities, school districts can by con- tract enter into an arrangement called a ‘“jointure,’’ which makes possible the pooling of resources by two or more districts to strengthen educational program offerings for increased numbers of pupils. A central unit for administration of all the district schools in a jointure is created under this plan. Since it is not a legal entity, a jointure may be terminated at the will of the contracting districts.

PUERTO RICO
District Superintendencies
There are 76 independent district school superintendencies, and all public schools are under the supervision of the superintendent of the independent dis- trict in which they are located. Enrollment data are as of September 1960.

SOUTH CAROLINA
County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 131 school superintendencies in the State: 24 complete county-unit,
22 county-intermediate, and 85 independent city or town superintendencies.
In
the 22 county-intermediate counties, the superintendent performs mainly a serv-
ice function.

SOUTH DAKOTA County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 319 school superintendencies in the State: 64 county-intermediate, 3 county-unit, and 252 independent city or town superintendencies. The super- intendents of the 64 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all admin- istrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Woodall’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in Aurora County (15) and the total number of pupils
enrolled in these districts (382).

TENNESSEE
County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 153 school superintendencies in the State: 55 complete county-unit superintendencies, 40 partial county-unit superintendencies, and 58 independent city or town superintendencies located within the 40 partial county-unit counties.

SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENCIES—TEXAS
TEXAS County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 1,152 school superintendencies in the State: 197 county-intermediate superintendencies, 47 partial county-unit superintendencies, 10 county-unit super- intendencies, and 898 city or town superintendencies. The superintendents in 128 of the 197 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operat- ing its schools independently. For example, in the parentheses before Superin- tendent Johnson’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in Anderson County (7) and the total number of pupils enrolled in
these districts (1,219). performs mainly a service function. (0) : zero districts, zero enrollment data.

UTAH County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 40 school superintendencies in the State: 22 complete, and 2 partial county-unit superintendencies, 11 county district superintendencies, and 5 inde- pendent city superintendencies. The counties of Juab, Salt Lake, Sanpete, and Utah, divided into 2 county districts, and Summit County, divided into 3 county districts, do not maintain an office of county superintendent. However, each of these county districts has its own superintendent, who is listed under the
county in which his office is located.

EDUCATION DIRECTORY, 1960-61 VERMONT
Supervisory Union and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 54 school superintendencies in the State: 44 supervisory union and 10 independent city superintendencies. There are no county school superin- tendents in the State. The general administration of public schools is under the jurisdiction of a supervisory union or independent city superintendent. In this State, two or more towns combine to form a supervisory union superintend- ency, each of which employs a superintendent who has jurisdiction over all
schools in the union.
Each supervisory union is designated by name and is
listed under the county in which it is located.

VIRGINIA
County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 115 school superintendencies (referred to as divisions) in the State: 85 county-unit (including 10 cases where 2 counties have combined and 5 cases where a county and a city have combined to form single county-unit superin- tendencies) and 30 independent city superintendencies.

WASHINGTON County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 303 school superintendencies in the State: 34 county-intermediate, 5 partial county-unit, and 264 independent city or town superintendencies. The superintendents in 28 of the 34 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the paren- theses before Superintendent Kinkade’s name are shown the number of dis- tricts whose functions he administers in Chelan County (4) and the total num- ber of pupils enrolled in these districts (221). In the remaining 6 counties, the county superintendent performs mainly a service function. Where this is true, it is indicated by (0) (0): zero districts, zero enrollment data.

EDUCATION DIRECTORY, 1960-61
WISCONSIN
County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 190 school superintendencies in the State: 71 county-intermediate superintendencies, one complete county-unit superintendency, and 118 inde-
pendent city or town superintendencies.
The superintendents of the 71 county-
intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools in- dependently. For example, in the parentheses before Superintendent Jones’
name are shown the number of districts whose functions he administers in
Adams County (7), and the total number of pupils enrolled in these districts

SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENCIES—WYOMING 201
WYOMING County and Independent School Superintendencies
There are 107 school superintendencies in the State: 21 county-intermediate, 2 partial county-unit, and 84 independent city or town superintendencies. The superintendents in 18 of the 21 county-intermediate superintendencies perform all administrative functions for areas comprised of two or more local districts, each district operating its schools independently. For example, in the paren- theses before Superintendent Nelson’s name are shown the number of districts whose functions she administers in Albany County (14) and the total number of
pupils enrolled in these districts (199).
superintendent performs mainly a service function.
In the remaining 3 counties, the county Where this is true, it is
indicated by (0) (0): zero districts, zero enrollment data.

Special Notice
IN THE UNITED STATES no reputable institution of higher education confers degrees solely on the basis of correspondence study. The lax chartering laws in some States permit the existence of correspondence schools whose practices amount virtually to the sale of degrees. Such organizations are commonly referred to as degree mills. The Secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare has defined a degree mill as “an organiza- tion that awards degrees without requiring courses of instruction that all reputable educational institutions require before conferring degrees.” Most of these de- gree mills operate solely by mail. In many cases staffs and plants do not even exist.
Degree mills are a serious threat to American educa- tional standards in several ways. First, they damage, by misunderstanding in the public mind, the legitimate and reputable correspondence schools which are filling an important and necessary role by providing corre- spondence study in the areas of vocational and adult edu- cation. Correspondence courses are also offered by some colleges and universities. But legitimate correspondence schools do not award degrees, and colleges and uni- versities do not award degrees on the basis of corre- spondence courses alone. Second, degree mills defraud those who honestly believe that they have received recog- nition from a legitimate institution of higher education. Third, they lower American prestige abroad by deceiv- ing foreign students. They cause legitimate American educational degrees to be undervalued because of the confusion overseas between bona fide institutions of higher education in the United States and the degree mills.
In view of the inadequacy and utter worthlessness of degree mills and their disservice to American higher education, the U.S. Office of Education strongly urges the public to be on guard against organizations adver- tising degrees based solely on correspondence study. Caution should also be exercised in evaluating degrees and other credentials, to ascertain whether or not they have been obtained from degree mills.
INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION—INTRODUCTION
CRITERIA FOR LISTING IN THIS DIRECTORY
INSTITUTIONS reported to the Office of Education as being in operation during 1959-60, offering at least a 2-year program of college-level studies in residence, willing to submit regularly and promptly the information required for listing, and meeting the cri- teria stated below, are included in this directory.
The criteria for listing in the directory are as follows:
1. Institutions accredited or approved by a nationally recognized accredit- ing agency, a State department of education, a State university, or operating under public control, are eligible for inclusion.
2. Institutions not meeting requirements of criterion 1 are eligible for in- clusion if their credits have been and are accepted as if coming from an accredited institution by not fewer than three accredited institutions.
CLASSIFICATION OF INSTITUTIONS
Institutions are classified by highest level of offering and by type of program.
The following categories have been established to designate insti- tutions by highest level of training:
I. 2 but less than 4 years of work beyond the 12th grade—includes junior colleges, technical institutes, and normal schools offering at least a 2-year program of college-level studies ;
II. Only the bachelor’s and/or first professional degree—includes those institutions offering courses of studies leading to the customary bach- elor of arts or bachelor of science degree, and all those degrees which entitle the possessor to enter the profession indicated; e.g., doctor of medicine, bachelor of pharmacy, or bachelor of science in engineering ;
III. Master’s and/or second professional degree—includes those institu- tions offering the customary first graduate degree, and any degree earned in the same field after the first professional degree, or after a bachelor’s degree in that field; eg., the degree of electrical engi- neer, earned after the bachelor of engineering, or the degree of doctor of science of law earned after the bachelor of laws degree;
IV. Doctor of philosophy and equivalent degrees; and
V. Other (explained by footnote).
2 EDUCATION DIRECTORY, 1960-61
The designations of institutions by type of program are as follows:
a. Terminal-occupational (below bachelor’s degree)—to represent a program not extending beyond the 14th or 15th grade, designed to prepare directly for an occupation, and not intended to prepare for advanced study;
b. Liberal arts and general—including those institutions offering a 4-year prograin leading to the bachelor’s degree ;
c. Liberal arts and general, and terminal-occupational—for institutions offer- ing programs described by a and Bb above;
d. Primarily teacher preparatory;
e. Liberal arts and general, and teacher preparatory;
f. Liberal arts and general, teacher preparatory, and terminal-occupational;
g. Professional or technical—including those institutions offering a program of occupational preparation (excluding teacher preparatory) ;
h. Professional or technical, and teacher preparatory ;
i. Professional or technical, and terminal-occupational;
j. Liberal arts and general with 1 or 2 professional schools; and
k. Liberal arts and general with 3 or more professional schools—including institutions organized as universities.
ARRANGEMENT OF DATA
An institution is listed in this directory under the State in which its post office is located. A branch institution is listed as a unit of the parent institution, with a cross reference to facilitate finding of the data. Arrangement of the data shown is uniform as follows:
For institutions organized as universities:
Name of institution, location (accreditation, control, student body, calendar system, code representing classification of institution by level of offering and type of program, enrollment).
Name of officers as follows:
President or chancellor. Dean. Chief business officer. Registrar and admissions officer. Librarian. Chief personnel officer and dean of men and dean of women. Dean or director of each professional school or college.’ Dean of graduate school. Director of summer session.
For other institutions of higher education having an enrollment of more
than 200: All data as above, except those relating to professional schools.
For institutions with enrollments of 200 or fewer:
Chief executive officer.
Chief academic officer.
Chief business officer.
Registrar or equivalent officer.
1Some universities maintain departments which are the equivalent of schools in other universities, but such departments are not listed unless they are separately organized with a dean or director in charge.
HIGHER EDUCATION 3
ABBREVIATIONS AND SYMBOLS
In parentheses immediately following the name and location of an institution, the abbreviations and symbols separated by semi- colons indicate six facts:
1. Accreditation of the institution by one or more of the nationwide or regional accrediting associations. 2. Control of the institution whether public, private, or denominational as reported by the institution. 3. The student body: coed.—coeducational—for both men and women. cord.—coordinate—separate colleges for men and women. men—for men students only. wo.—women—for women students only. 4, Calendar system on which the institution operates: semester, quarter, or other. 5. Code representing classification by highest level of offering and by type of program. 6. Enrollment of regular college students in the fall of 1959.

ACCREDITATION
Institutions with liberal arts and general programs and, in some cases, those with special programs are accredited by six regional accrediting associations. These associations are indicated throughout this directory by the following abbreviations:
E., New England Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools.
M., Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools.
N., North Central Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools,
NW., Northwest Association of Secondary and Higher Schools.
S., Southern Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools.
W., Western College Association.
¢Preceding any of the letters listed above or the abbreviations given below indicates that the institution is provisionally accredited, or accredited with some reservation, or is admitted on probation.
—Not accredited by any nationwide or regional accrediting association.
Professional schools are accredited by the following associations. The abbreviations are those used throughout the directory to repre- sent accreditation by the appropriate organization.
Accrediting Association of Bible Colleges: Bible (Bi).
Accrediting Commission for Business Schools: Business (jeb) (seb).
American Association of Collegiate Schools of Business: Business (bus).
American Association of Schools of Religious Education: Religious educa- tion (rel).
American Association of Theological Schools: Theology (theol).
American Bar Association, Section of Legal Education and Admission to the Bar: Law (law).
American Chemical Society, Committee on Professional Training: Chemistry (chem).
American Council on Education for Journalism: Journalism (jour).
American Council on Pharmaceutical Education : Pharmacy (phar).

American Podiatry Association : Podiatry (pod).

nical institute curricula (tech).

The accreditation or approval of institutions of higher education by State departments of education or State universities is not shown in this directory, but may be found in Office of Education Bulletin 1960, No. 24, entitled Accredited Higher Institutions.?
Notre.—The Office of Education does not accredit or approve any educational institutions.
CONTROL
The legal control of institutions (not support or affiliation), as reported by each institution, is shown with the following abbrevia- tions:
C.—City or municipal government—public control.
Church—Refer to abbreviations—denominational control.
Co.—County government—public control.
Dist.—District government—public control.
Nat.—National or Federal Government—public control.
P.—Private; independent of church or state—private control; tax-exempt. Prop.—Proprietary, incorporated as non-tax-exempt.
2The names and addresses of executive secretaries of regional and professional accredit- ing associations may be found in Bulletin 1960, No. 24.
HIGHER EDUCATION 9
St.—State government—public control. Ter.—Territorial government—public control. Twp.—Township government—public control.
CALENDAR
The calendar system on which each institution operates is indicated by the following designations: Sem.—semester. Qr.—quarter or trimester. Term—unit other than semester or quarter, explained by footnote.
ENROLLMENT
For each institution for which data are available, the total enroll- ment of students of college grade, excluding correspondence students, in the fall of 1959 is given. Where figure is italicized, the enrollment is estimated. For institutions classified as terminal-occupational, total resident enrollment, whether classified as collegiate or not, is given.
Table 1.—Institutions of higher education, by type of program and by level

University. The Board main- tains its offices in Tallahassee, and J. B. Culpepper is the Exeeutive Director.

Board of Higher Education is charged with the responsibility of promot- ing the development and operation of a pro- gressive and coordinated system. The chief executive officer of the board is J. 34The Oklahoma State System of Higher Education by law includes all State-owned institutions of higher learning. Independ- ent institutions may apply for affiliation. The Oklahoma State Regents for Higher Education (M. A. Nash, Chancellor, Okla- homa City) is by law the coordinating board for all institutions of higher learning in the State. Each institution has its own govern- ing board. The State Regents allocate funds and determine functions for the State- owned institutions.

35 The State system of higher education in Oregon includes all the State-supported higher educational institutions. The chief executive officer is the Chancellor, John R. Richards, Eugene, Oreg. The State system also operates a General Extension Division, credits earned in which are accepted by the University of Oregon, Oregon State College, Oregon College of Education, Portland State College, Southern Oregon College and East- ern Oregon College.

ISSUED ANNUALLY
The Education Directory of the Office of Education is issued annually in the following parts:
1. Federal Government and States. | 2. Counties and Cities. 3. Higher Education.
*4. Education Associations.
As soon as each part is off the press, copies may be purchased at nominal cost through the Superintendent of Docu-
ments, U.S. Government Printing Office, Washington 25, D.C.
*Part 4, Education Associations, was prepared in Publi- cations Services, Office of Education, by Bobbie Doud.

PART 4 EDUCATION ASSOCIATIONS

TIES, AND RECOGNITION SOCIETIES (NATIONAL)..... A5 MrATE EDUCATION ASSOCIATIONS............2ccecce0s 57 MID OIONS. 00 cw cc cc ee ee we eee n eee ceseeees 96 RELIGIOUS EDUCATION ASSOCIATIONS................ 99 INTERNATIONAL EDUCATION ASSOCIATIONS............ 105 OSES sabe gee ce 107
THIS DIRECTORY contains information based upon replies to a questionnaire sent by the Office of Education to education associations and organizations. The fact that an association or organization is listed in the Directory does not imply that the Office of Education either recommends or evaluates it.
The first item in a listing is the organization’s name, followed by the address of headquarters, if any; the second, name and address of the head (president, chairman, director, etc.); the third, name and address of the secretary; the fourth, expiration date of president’s term; the fifth, title(s) of the official periodic publication(s) and frequency of issue. If no address appears for the head or the secre- tary, it is the same as that for the organization.
The frequency of publication is shown by abbreviations: an. (an- nual); bien. (biennial); bm. (bimonthly); bw. (biweekly); ir. (irreg- ular); m. (monthly); nos. (number issued each year); q. (quarterly) ; sa. (semiannual); sm. (semimonthly); trien. (triennial); w. (weekly).
NATIONAL AND REGIONAL EDUCATION ASSOCIATIONS
THE FIRST SECTION covers, in a single alphabet, the following types of associations: (1) associations of educators and other persons directly concerned with schools and colleges; (2) community health, service, or social welfare groups that relate certain of their activities to school and college programs; (3) historical, learned, professional, research and scientific organizations growing out of or related to school and college activities; (4) library and museum associations; (5) organizations sponsoring youth group activities in schools and colleges or supplementing school or college programs.

COLLEGE PROFESSIONAL FRATERNITIES, HONOR SOCIETIES, AND RECOGNITION SOCIETIES (NATIONAL)
THIS SECTION lists national professional fraternities and honor and recognition societies that maintain chapters in colleges and uni- versities and admit as members enrolled students, either undergradu-
ate or graduate, or both.
If membership is restricted to men or
women only, that fact is indicated in the listing.

STATE EDUCATION ASSOCIATIONS
THIS SECTION, confined to organizations on a statewide basis, lists teacher associations; elementary, secondary, and higher education associations; associations of school administrators and of school boards; parent-teacher and library associations. It is not feasible to include in this Directory State organizations in subject matter fields and other special areas. Information about these State organizations may be available from State departments of education.

RELIGIOUS EDUCATION ASSOCIATIONS
THIS SECTION lists national and regional education associations
under religious denominational or interdenominational control that do one or more of the following: operate colleges; operate sectarian schools attended by students who go there instead of going to public or private schools; supplement the regular school program by offer- ing educational activities for youth and adults; operate adult educa- tional programs open to the public; formally promote scholarship among their members in sciences and liberal arts.
